p: More species have been reported as possessing pharmacological activity in the Middle East. A report from Saudi Arabia describes E. arabicum being found to exert antiplasmodial and antitrypanosomal activity [ 40]. In Jordan, E. glomeratum (locally known, ‘ Sag Al-hamam’) is said to possess analgesic, diaphoretic, and aphrodisiac effects and has been used for the treatment of snake bites. E. judaeum (‘ Lesan Al-Thoor’) has also been used in the Jordanian provinces for its sedative effects, managing hyperactivity, anxiety, and improving certain dermatological conditions [ 41].
